I'm so glad I found Andrew Huberman and all of his channels, because they have helped me feel so understood in so many ways, physiologically, mentally, chemically, emotionally, etc. 

One thing I really resonated with (amongst many topics in this episode) was when Andrew was talking about being kinesthetically tuned (14:06), and how some people experience their thoughts through a patchwork of sensation in the body. I have never in my life been able to identify with something more than that distinction/framework of thought processing. Coming to the conclusion that not everyone experiences the sensation of thoughts within the body is groundbreaking for me because I genuinely believed that everyone did. I now realize the reason why I frequently get frustrated when I try to learn new things using an intellectual framework and fail miserably or just struggle to understand in general is because my brain does not retain information through thought-connection, but rather thought-sensation-connection. 

For example, for me, I can read/research a subject as much as I want, but the content of that research will not 'click' or be retained in my brain until I reach a point where I physically feel or am able to identify a specific concept with a particular sensation. It's like all my 'Aha!' moments have to be accompanied by a degree of sensation or associated with a degree of emotion before I can actually begin to understand what I'm learning about. Or another example, I often use music (various genres) to understand concepts I can't understand through reading, by paying attention to the potential shifts in vibration/patterns within the melody and how they contribute to the overall emotional expression/message of the song through lyrics. It's given me so much insight, I never would have known that kinesthetically tuned even existed as a term that describes thought processes had I not taken the time to explore an episode like this one. But now I can find new ways to process information/learn that work for my type of thought process. Like I said before, GROUNDBREAKING. 

Andrew, you are a godsend. Keep up the good work because you're helping so many people come to conclusions retrospectively that they probably would have never been able to reach without watching you discuss it publicly and civilly in the same gracious and intellectual way you do. Thank you.
